step.value: Artificial intelligence has gotten so good at mimicking parts of human cognition that now we often only see the glitches…
... for example, when autofill presents the wrong words in a text, when Spotify pulls up a dud of a song.
But why do those glitches happen? And why are machines getting better and better at doing what we do?
To understand how AI works, you have to understand how human cognition works, and recognize all of the processes we take for granted.
The brain is the one part of our body we don't think of as mechanical, but cognition that seems to happen in an instant is actually a series of steps, which is a lot like how an algorithm works.
In this interactive, we're slowing down the process to show you, step by step, how our brain works.

text.value: Artificial intelligence is transforming the world: how we travel, how we communicate, and how we live. But the AI researchers building these tools aren’t working from scratch. These capabilities take inspiration from how brains learn new things.
Click here to see how…

btn.text: How do recognize a piece of music?

text.value: Almost half of your brain is devoted to the visual system. Computer vision, the area of AI that deals with how machines see the world, is getting some of the most interest. Some of the most funding -- and controversy -- is being generated by face recognition programs used for everything from … to …. To understand how they work, you first need to understand how we see faces.

Within about 200 milliseconds of seeing a photo, your brain can decide whether it’s viewing a face or some other object. We have neurons in our visual cortex dedicated just to faces, aptly called face cells, which register different features and the spatial relationship between them.

btn.text: What we see in a face

text.value: To your brain, a face is not a single object, but a combination of features. The most important landmarks seem to be the eyes, mouth, and -- surprisingly enough -- eyebrows.
Can you guess who is this?
Here’s the same person’s face, but with none of their features removed.
Now can you guess who this is?

Most objects are harder to recognize when they are seen upside-down, but faces are especially difficult. It’s possible that because those landmarks are not where face cells expect them to be, other parts of the visual cortex have to become involved. We eventually get it, but it takes longer.
Can you guess who is this?
Here’s the same person’s face, but oriented the way we’re used to seeing it.
Now can you guess who this is?

Shown an upside-down photo of Tom Cruise, AI draws a blank. One of Kim Kardashian confuses the system so much it thinks it is looking at Ozzy Osbourne. It’s unclear why the AI is wrong, but it is likely the system was never trained on upside-down portraits and can’t generalize.

Face recognition software also relies on learning the different parts and of a face, and the distance between them. People can recognize about 5,000 faces, while AI can learn millions and identify those individuals in moments. But these systems have plenty of weaknesses we don’t. It might take a person a beat longer to recognize Kim Kardashian without eyebrows, but the neural networks is only about 35 percent sure it's her.

visual.title: AI and racial profiling of faces
visual.caption: Members of Congress misidentified by Amazon’s Rekognition software (clockwise from top left) Rep. John Lewis, Rep. Luis V. Gutiérrez, Rep. Bobby Rush, Sen. Edward J. Markey.

text.value: Some of the errors made much more damaging consequences than not recognizing a celebrity. AI software has been shown to make more mistakes on dark-skinned individuals, especially women. This is largely due to the algorithm being trained on a lot of photos of white men. At least two police departments using Amazon’s face recognition software falsely matched photos of 28 members of Congress with mug shots in a test done by the ACLU. Eleven of those false matches -- almost 40% -- were non-white representatives. That’s double the amount of false matches overall. Between kinks in the technology and social biases built into the datasets, many activists don’t think facial recognition is ready for widespread use.

btn.text: How face recognition is being used

visual.title: How face recognition software is being used
visual.caption: A demonstration of NEC's video face recognition technology.

text.value: Cities around the country are passing laws to protect privacy that regulate how agencies, including police, can use face recognition software. But places like stadiums and airports are unregulated and are rolling out the technology, which they argue will keep people safe and make lines faster.

AI might not even be the best innovation for law enforcement. A few years ago, the London police department created a new team made up of super recognizers, or people who can recognize thousands of faces, often after one glimpse or even years later. In 2016, the group made about 2,500 positive identifications in criminal cases, compared to 4,500 for forensic sciences like DNA. The science behind what gives these individuals suped-up face recognizing power isn’t clear, and research hasn’t been able to find any structural differences in the brain. It’s possible this skill is just an extreme case of what being wired to recognize faces looks like.

When we listen to someone speak, our brains make educated guesses about what’s coming next. Artificial intelligence uses a similar process to predict what words you’ll text next on your phone.

speech.title: This word could save your life

text.value: For our ancestors to adapt and survive, our brain had to establish the relationship between sensory events, like the sounds of speech. And being able to make a guess about what comes next could save precious seconds in life or death situations. To do that, specific neurons in our auditory cortex respond to different phonemes, the smallest units of sound that distinguish one word from another. In English, there are 44 phonemes, like “w” and “f” and “t.”
It’s hard to pick the “right” word without context.
Those groups of neurons learn the relationship between different sounds and the possibility that they go together to predict what might come next.
What word comes next?

AI that predicts text, like the ones that provide the next word in the iPhone’s messaging app or Gmail’s new Smart Compose suggestions that tries to guess what you are writing in an email, also relies on understanding relationships. For these AIs, they learn the correlation between letters, words, and sentences after being trained on millions of documents.

speech.title: How AI learns the worst from us

text.value: The problem with training AI on old documents is that it learns human biases. Google Translate used to turn the Turkish phrase “O bir doktor” into “He is a doctor,” despite “o” being a gender-neutral third-person pronoun. Why? The algorithm just saw more examples of doctors being identified as men and learned that relationship. Google now offers up both a “he” and “she” translation. A recent study shows how this bias is alive and well in humans—just 5 percent of people assume a doctor is a woman, despite making up 44 percent of the profession.

More research into exactly what the brain does might help with dyslexics who struggle to read at speed and are missing the predictive ability. Already, AI-assisted tools like Grammarly are already helping dyslexics fix spelling errors and divining what they meant to write.

This is the most cutting edge language model out there, maybe a separate slide to highlight would be good? https://talktotransformer.com/. Could be fun to do an example of it. Like if I put in “For our ancestors to adapt and survive” the model comes back with: “ ichthyosaurs had to get used to it, and we're still waiting to learn how the rest of the world adapted. If that's good enough for you, stay tuned; I believe we have our answers.”

We pair music with the most important events in our lives, from hummed lullabies to war drums to weddings hymns to funeral dirges. But what makes a song feel right for a moment or mood? Our brains rely on a combination of hard-wired responses and preferences learned over time to pick the perfect song. Spotify, and other AI-driven music services, start with similar methods but add a whole lot more to build the perfect customized playlist.

Our auditory cortex responds selectively to music-like sounds, but not to speech or non-musical environmental sounds and noises. There are still a lot of unanswered questions, like sorting out if there are other brain regions involved in music processing, and when these systems develop, but it’s clear that there are some ways that our brains are hard-wired to make sense of music.

music.title: Are my sad songs sadder than yours?

text.value: There is, of course, a major cultural component in how we perceive music, but at least one study shows that we respond to music in similar ways regardless of our background. Researchers had Cameroon tribe members with no exposure to Western culture listen to and label a pop song happy or sad. They could, although their rates weren’t as spot-on as western participants.

music.title: If you’re happy and you know it...

text.value: Where does this music fall on a scale from happiest to saddest?

You might have had a sense of how happy a song is even if you haven’t heard it before, but AI has to be taught. The happiness — or lack thereof —  of a piece of music is measured with a metric called valence. Songs with high valence, anything above 0.5, sound happier, while tracks below that sound sadder. Spotify had music experts teach an AI the valence of some songs and that algorithm was applied to the rest of the songs on the platform. The rules are a secret sauce but we do know they are fine-tuned regularly.
Here’s how your answers compared to Spotify’s valence measurements.

music.title: An AI playlist just for you

text.value: To put together a Discover Weekly playlist, a unique set of songs that you haven’t heard but might enjoy, Spotify has three recommendation models they rely on (with some extra rules they hard code in, like no Christmas music after December 25th). One looks at the raw audio for data points like valence, but also the time signature, what key it is in, the tempo, and danceability. Spotify rates a song’s “danceabilty” based on including tempo, rhythm stability, beat strength, and overall regularity.
Where does this music fall on a scale from least to most danceable?
Here’s how your answers compared to Spotify’s valence measurements.

Another metric compares your listening history to other users. If you and a friend have similar tastes, your friend might jam to something that you haven’t heard yet. The final tool looks at text on the internet including news articles and blogs. A non-algorithmic consideration? Playlists put together by everyone from casual listeners to professionals hired by Spotify. Songs that a user saves on their own playlists are also given more weight.[i]
Why AI sometimes gets it wrong

music.title: The right data, the wrong song [j]

text.value: Even with all this data, the Spotify recommendation engine sometimes offers a song that it thinks you should love but you hate. Spotify’s approach relies on technical elements, while things that matter to listeners, like context, aren’t considered, says Valerio Velardo the CEO of an AI music company called Melodrive. “You can't expect to have a perfect friend to suggest perfect music for you all the time, and you can't expect the recommendation systems to do it either."

No matter the taste or who (or what algorithm) introduces it to you, music leaves an impression on the brain. According to recent research, the part of your brain that responds to music doesn’t get lost to Alzheimer’s. Music that was meaningful can even pull a person out of the haze for a short while. Music moves us through time, bringing memories into vivid relief. Music is essential to what makes us human, and this is proof.
